title: Paul
content: The life and work of the great Apostle Paul is recorded at considerable length in the Acts and the epistles. It is only possible to indicate here a few of the chief facts. He was known in early life as Saul; his Latin name Paul is first mentioned at the beginning of his gentile ministry (
). He belonged to Tarsus, in Cilicia (
); was a Pharisee and a pupil of Gamaliel (
); was active in the persecution of Christians (
); and took part in the martyrdom of Stephen (
). He started for Damascus for the purpose of further persecution (
) and on the road saw a vision of the Lord Jesus, which changed the whole current of his life (
) and then returned to Damascus, where he preached (
). Being compelled to flee, about three years after his conversion he went to Jerusalem, where he stayed 15 days, Barnabas introducing him to Peter and James (
). Being in danger, he retired to Tarsus (
) and there remained six or seven years, preaching in Syria and Cilicia (
). He was then brought by Barnabas to Antioch (
) and after one year paid a visit to Jerusalem (
). After two more years’ work in Antioch, he started with Barnabas and Mark on his first missionary journey (
). Then came another visit to Jerusalem with Barnabas to attend a conference with the other Apostles (
), after which they returned to Antioch (
). He then started on his second missionary journey (
), which lasted about three years and ended with a visit to Jerusalem. After a short stay in Antioch, Paul began his third journey, which occupied about 3½ years (
). On his return to Jerusalem he was arrested and sent to Caesarea (
), where he remained a prisoner for two years (
), and was then sent for trial to Rome, suffering shipwreck on the way (
). He remained in Rome two years (

) and was then released. He then appears to have visited Asia, Macedonia, Crete, and perhaps Spain. At the end of about four years he was again taken a prisoner to Rome and suffered martyrdom, probably in the spring of
65. For an account of his teaching, see
